quoteLast: , we resumed our seats in Mr. C.'s phaeton, and by the nearest route across the country, returned to Lear's. Mr. C. entertained us by the way with eulogies upon the industry and faithfulness of his apprentices.
title: The Anti-Slavery Examiner, Omnibus

quoteFirst: Egremont became impatient, and declared that the valet had no business to keep the child out so long; indeed, he would sooner have taken alarm but for Nuttie's manifest agony of anxiety, starting and rushing to listen at every ring at the bell or sound of wheels near at hand.  At last,
quoteLast: , there was a peal of the servants' bell, and the footman who answered it turned round to the anxious crowd: 'Mr. Gregory!  He just asked if the child was come home, and went off like lightning.
title: Nuttie's Father
author: Yonge, Charlotte M. (Charlotte Mary), 1823-1901

quoteFirst: "I had coffee at five o'clock; for myself I never worry. I'm glad enough you feel all right. It's
quoteLast: , Abie--I go me to bed. To-morrow I go to market with Yetta."
title: Just Around the Corner: Romance en casserole
author: Hurst, Fannie, 1889-1968

quoteFirst: After a supper at the “Soldier’s Rest,” the regiment took the cars about
quoteLast: , and reached Monocacy Junction a little before noon the next day, going into camp in a reaped grain-field, near the still smoking ruins of the depot, and in the vicinity of the battle-field of Monocacy, where the first division of the corps was then in camp.
title: The story of the Thirty Eighth regiment of Massachusetts volunteers
author: Powers, George Whitefield, 1834-1903

quoteFirst: On Tuesday, the 18th, the Marechal d'Estrees took him,
quoteLast: in the morning, to his house at Issy, gave him a dinner, and much amused him during the day with many things shown to him relating to the navy.
title: Memoirs of Louis XIV and His Court and of the Regency — Volume 11
author: Saint-Simon, Louis de Rouvroy, duc de, 1675-1755

quoteFirst: When I had finished my second cup of tea and glanced through the morning paper,
quoteLast: was striking.  I rose, went to the window, and looked out upon Piccadilly, bright and brilliant in the morning sun. With hands in my pockets I stood debating whether I should act upon a suggestion that had been constantly in my mind ever since leaving Paris.
title: Her Majesty's Minister
author: Le Queux, William, 1864-1927

quoteFirst: When the train rolled into the Gare du Nord, it must have been about
quoteLast: in the evening. X. had explained to me that, in order to make my entrance into Paris properly gay and interesting, we were to dine at the Café de Paris, then visit the Folies-Bergère, and afterward have supper at the Abbaye Thélème. Now, as usual, X. was alert and prepared.
title:
